Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Living Patio Umbrella: Customer Discovery in the Restaurant, Hospitality, Recreation, Institutional and Entertainment Industries
Award.AbstractNarration:
The outdoor dining, hospitality, recreation, building, property management and entertainment industries, as well as homeowners and institutions, strive to provide comfortable and environmentally friendly places for people to eat, lounge, play, study, congregate, and socialize outside. In today's modern economy, many people spend the vast majority of their time indoors, but would prefer to be outdoors. However, for people to be comfortable outdoors in many situations, they need places that are shady, cool, inviting and comfortable; for it to be environmentally friendly they need the comfort delivered using sustainable practices and materials. Patio umbrellas are a common way to shade outdoor space, with about $500 million sold annually. Commercial grade patio umbrellas often sell in the range of $150010,000. Conventional patio umbrellas provide shade and some comfort, but they do little else for people. Plants, like trees, are often thought of in the same breath as shade (think "shade tree"). Plants not only block the Sun, but they also use water to cool the air surrounding them, provide beauty and naturalness, and are known to remove poisonous chemicals from the air. Plants are being used more and more on the roofs and walls of buildings to make them more environmentally friendly. This team has invented the Living Patio Umbrella which has the artificial canopy of a conventional umbrella replaced by plants. The invention is unique because of its modular structural design, novel placement of the soil container, and its micro-controlled, automated irrigation system.

Preliminary Customer Discovery (CD), conducted as part of the UMD I-Corps regional program, provided feedback on 1) the technical design, 2) the ability to meet specific needs of customer segments (i.e., restaurants, property management, architecture, and resorts) and 3) insight on business models that we should consider. The team's aim for the NSF I-Corps national program is to continue customer discovery as part of the Lean Startup process to determine whether the team's initial hypotheses about the value propositions fit with the needs of identified customer segments. The team also aims to use the Business Model Canvas to develop and test hypotheses about how to operationalize the living umbrella into a green startup. The team will attend the course kickoff, participate in NSF webinars, interview at least 100 customers, and attend NSF's lessons learned session. In addition, the team intends to interview potential key partners, such as nurseries, to test hypotheses about business models for the proposed startup. If a strong product market fit is discovered, then the research team will form a Startup company named Living Canopies Ltd. to commercialize the Living Umbrella under exclusive license from the University of Maryland.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Justification and Objectives

The outdoor dining, hospitality, recreation, and other industries strive to provide comfortable and environmentally friendly places for people to eat, lounge, play, and socialize outside. To be comfortable outdoors, people need places that are shady, cool, inviting and comfortable. Conventional patio umbrellas are a common way to shade outdoor space, but they do little else for people. Plants are synonomous with shade. Plants not only block the Sun, but they also use water to cool the air, provide beauty and naturalness, and are known to remove poisonous chemicals.  We invented the Living Patio Umbrella which has the artificial canopy of a conventional umbrella replaced by plants. UMD's Office of Technology Commercialization filed a provisional patent in October.  

This project sought to determine what the value propositions of the Living Umbrella were for the restaurant customer segment. We aimed to explore the thoughts and reactions of the general public to our Living Umbrella. We wanted to determine whether a commercially viable and scalable business model could be developed that was centered on the Livng Umbrella technology.

We participated in the I-Corps Southwest program in Houston from late January, 2016 to early March, 2016 to learn the Lean Startup approach.  We built a minimum viable product and placed it in public view on the University of Maryland campus where we engaged individuals to probe their thoughts on its values.

Findings

During the NSF I-Corps program we conducted 101 interviews with architects, restaurant owners and managers, hotel and resort owners and managers, city sustainability officers, homeowners, and apartment managers as part of our Customer Discovery (CD). CD provided feedback on value propositions, what customer segments valued, and product market fit. Going into the project we did not realize the difference between product features and value propositions (VP). We learned that features are the attributes that define the physical product. The VP’s, on the other hand, are what the customer values--its what motivates them to make a purchase because it will fix a pain or add a gain for their business.

Conducting interviews taught us the value of listening to customers. At the beginning of I-Corps we did not understand customer empathy. On the first day of interviewing in Houston, we would show nice photographs of our technology. Interviewees would compliment us on our invention and say things like, “you will have the hotels and restaurant buyers lined up around the block.” The praise was welcomed, but we weren’t learning why they liked it. We were not developing any empathy. That night a panelists said, “Don’t show them your underwear!” We changed our interview strategy. No more showing our product or explaining it. We were there to listen, not talk. We asked open-ended questions and heard stories about pains and gains which opened a window into their minds. It showed us their way of thinking and decision making. We gained authentic insight when they used their own language.

The course instruction on Lean Startup taught us the nine main elements of the business model canvas and helped us generate a viable and scalable business model. We developed a Get, Keep and Grow strategy to relate to customers; a strategy for delivering our product to customers; and a revenue model that was a combination of asset sale and subscription. The iterative process of generating our business model canvas was helpful in exploring the basis for each of the 9 elements and selecting a way forward that fit best with the overall strategy. The business model canvas was helpful because it made us think of the interconnectedness of the nine elements.

The demonstration of the minimum viable product on the University of Maryland campus revealed that overwhelming number of people loved our invention. Our undergraduate capstone team found that over 75% of participants who sat under the living umbrella said it made them feel happy.

Broader Impacts

The living umbrella team’s four co-founders formed Living Canopies Ltd to commercialize our technology. We will acquire an exclusive license agreement with the University of Maryland. I-Corps gave us the insight we needed on product market fit and how to develop a viable and scalable business model. We were awarded a grant from Maryland’s technology development corporation (TEDCO) in June and a campus grant at the same time.

The insight on developing empathy for people as part of the Lean Startup had the most impact on us as environmental researchers. Thinking more deeply about empathy revealed that most people are woefully ill-prepared to empathize. Its not taught in schools. We have started an interaction with the US EPA’s Office of Research and Development to pursuade them to pursue environmental entrepreneurship and customer empathy as they assist communities with health and sustainability.


Last Modified: 08/03/2016
Modified by: David R Tilley
